She has retained in the West Indies, Cuba, Porto Rico, and the Virgin Isles, containing altogether 39,799 square miles, and 1,511,660 inhabitants; in the East Indies, the Philippine Islands, 53,148 square miles with 2,679,500 inhabitants; in Africa, the Presichos and Guinea Islands, with 516 square miles, and 17,071 inhabitants, besides the new acquisitions in Morocco, of which we have no statistics; and in Oceanica, part of the Ladrone Islands, 592 square miles in extent.-- The Spanish empire thus numbers about twenty millions of people, in a territory of some two hundred and ninety thousand square miles.
If Spain, like Sardinia, will reform her internal organization, and adopt in the government of her colonies, especially Cuba, a more liberal policy towards foreign nations, we do not see why her regeneration and expansion should not prove as great and remarkable as that of Sardinia.

In regard to Cuba, we have always held that Mr. Calhoun was right in his opposition to the schemes of filibustering and annexation which have been so sedulously promoted by those commercial classes in the large cities of the North, who, as in the case of Texas and California, would be the chief and probably the only gainers by Cuban annexation.
On the score of national right and justice, first of all, and then of expediency and policy, we have all along believed that this country should cleanse its skirts of this unhallowed greed for the property and possessions of a friendly power.
It has been, beyond all question, alike the duty and the interest of the Southern States to promote the most friendly relations with Spain, an empire which has similar institutions to our own, and whose lofty and chivalric character has many points of resemblance to that of the Southern people.
There has been a time when Spain was the first commercial and colonial power in the world, and when her adventurous heroes carried her flag in glory over the greater part of this continent.
Her commerce is again rising to importance, her circlet of colonial gems is more likely to be increased than diminished.
and her late war with Morocco shows that her heroic days have not yet ended.
She has a respectable army and navy, even for a European power, in point of numbers, and in courage and efficiency the soldiers of Spain are equal to those of any country in the old world.
We must not judge the Spaniards by their degenerate descendants in this hemisphere.
There is great dignity and stamina in the Spanish character, high resolve and unconquerable pride.
We shall rejoice to see Spain, learning wisdom from the errors and misfortunes of the past, begin a new career of enterprise and prosperity.

div3.head: New Jersey.
div3.p: --The Newark Advertiser claims that one Republican Elector is chosen in that State, and perhaps four.
At Leavenworth, K. T., on the reception of the news of Lincoln's election, the streets were illuminated, salutes fired, and the "Wide Awakes" paraded with full ranks.
Walter F. Leake, of Richmond, delivered the annual address before the Agricultural Society of Cumberland, N. C., on 13th inst.
The reward of $1,000 offered for the recovery of the body of Miss Agnes Garth, lost in the Lady Elgin, has been paid.
Thomas Shoulders was killed in Northampton county, N. C., a few days since, by the falling of a tree.
Judge J. B. Eccleston, one of the Judges of the Maryland Court of Appeals, died on the 12th inst.
Breckinridge's majority in Maryland is now ascertained to be over 800.

div3.head: Married,
div3.p: On the 14th inst., by the Rev. Mr. Willis, Edgar C. Rowe, of Fredericksburg, to Miss Emma Sledd, of Richmond.

div2.head:
Marine intelligence.
port of Richmond, November 14.
high water this day (Thursday) 6 ¼ o'clock.

Also, for sale, a young, No. 1 Riding Horse, perfectly gentle in harness.

div3.head: $20 reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away on Saturday, the 3d inst. from the employment of Dr. John B. Eastham.
of Louisa county, a Negro Man, named Ralph, belonging to the estate of Jesse Perkins, dec'd..

Ralph is about twenty-two years of age, black, and about five feet five inches high.
No peculiar mark about him is remembered.
He. it is said, can write a good hand, and is probably making his way to a free State.
The above reward will be paid for his apprehension in the State and delivery to us, or being placed in jail so that we get him; or, if taken out of the State and delivered to us, or placed in a jail in this State, so that we get him, a reward of $100 will be paid.
div3.closer:
Wm. Crawford,
John R. Quarles.
Frank T. West,
Ex'ers of Jesse Perkins, dec'd..
Trevillian's Depot, Louisa co.,Nov. 12th 1860. no 14--ts

div3.head: $50 reward.
div3.p:
--Runaway from my plantation.
in the county of Halifax, near Clover Depot, on the 22d of August, a negro man named William.
He is bright complected; about 5 feet 8 or 9 inches height rather stout; has very large feet and hands; holes in his ears.
He was taken up at Keysville about the middle of September, but made his escape.-- He was heard to say that he was trying to get to Williamsburg, where he was raised.
He was sold by Dr. Garrett, of that place, about six years ago. I think it very probable that he is in Williamsburg, or working about Richmond.
I will pay $50 reward for his delivery or lodgment in jail where I can get him, if taken up out of the county; if in the county, a liberal reward.
James B. Carden.
no 9--d6tcw2t] Clover Depot; Hall ax co., Va.

div3.head: Seventy-five dollars reward.
div3.p:
--I will pay $75 00 for the apprehension of my Negro Girl, Peggy, who absconded about three weeks ago, She is a low, thick set mulatto, with short curly hair, and is about sixteen years old. Her dress cannot be described.
as she has been seen several times in this city since she left, and had on a different dress each time.
div3.closer:
E. L. Chinn.
Richmond, Oct. 25, 1860. oc 26--ts

div3.head: $20 reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from Mr. W. J. Worsham, about the 1st of May last, a Negro Woman, named Isabella.
She belonged to Ro. B. Corbin, of Camline, and may be lurking about his farm, where she has a child, or in this city, where she has been hired for several years past.
She is of middle size and dark brown complexion.
She wore ear rings.
and was quite tidy in her dress.
The above reward will be paid upon her delivery to us, or her confinement in jail where we can get her.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 18, Number 117, page 3.

div3.head: From Washington.
div3.p: --It is authoritatively announced that the President has never publicly or privately pledged himself to secession, as Hon. Mr. Keitt is reported to have asserted in a recent speech.

The postmaster at Orangeburg, South Carolina, has tendered his resignation, to take effect on the 1st of January, unless South Carolina secedes sooner than that time.
His resignation has been accepted, and he is requested to name his successor.
In the event of his not procuring one who will give the necessary bonds, the office will be discontinued.
Col. Gardner, in the ordinary routine, has been relieved from the command of Fort Moultrie, Maj. Anderson, next in rank, has been appointed as his successor.

div3.head: Secession and Unionism in Georgia.
div3.p:
--Speeches are made nightly in this place by Senator Toombs, Thos. R. Cobb, and others, in favor of secession.
Hon. Messrs. Stephens and Johnson, and others, are opposed.
The friends of Iverson, in the Georgia Legislature, are in favor of Hon. Howell Cobb for U. S. Senator.
Nothing of interest has transpired in Milledgeville to-day.

div3.head: From California.
div3.p:
--The Pony Express, from San Francisco, has arrived.
The steamship Uncle Sam sailed from there on the 1st, with $1,802,000 in treasure, for New York.
Oregon advices to the 27th ult, are received, but are unimportant.
New York, Nov. 14.--The steamer North Star has arrived from Aspinwall with $926,000 in California treasure.

div3.head: The capture of Fort Moultrie.
div3.p: --The Mercury, referring to a dispatch published in the Philadelphia Inquirer about the taking of Fort Moultrie, pronounces it utterly unfounded, and says unless Northern journals send out more reliable agents, they must expect to suffer in their pockets, as well as have their fears excited by unjust apprehensions.

div3.head: New Jersey election.
div3.p:
--The official returns elect Cooke, Parker and Renegan, Douglas Democrats; Hornblower, Elmer, Ivins and Sendder, Republicans, to represent New Jersey in the next Congress of the United States.
The former have over 3,000, the latter majorities ranging from 100 to 1,500.

div3.head: Military at Lincoln's Inauguration.
div3.p:
--The Burgess Company, a military company of this city, to-day voted to visit Washington on the occasion of Lincoln's Inauguration.
They will probably carry about one hundred men.

div3.head: Accident on the Camden and Amboy Railroad.
div3.p:
--A train on the Camden and Amboy Railroad ran off the track near Burlington, this morning.
Three cars were smashed.
An employee was slightly injured.

div3.head: Destruction of a Rice Mill.
div3.p:
--The Mercury reports the burning of West Point Rice Mills last night.
Loss, from 2,000 to 3,000 bushels of rice.
Total loss $75,000. The fire was caused by friction from the machinery.

div3.head: Senator Douglas.
div3.p: --It is reported that a dispatch was received in Milledgville, yesterday, reporting Senator Douglas exceedingly ill at some place, probably in Mississippi.

div3.head: South Carolina Bank restrictions.
div3.p: --The South Carolina Legislature, before its adjournment, removed all restrictions against Bank suspensions.

div3.head: Obituary.
div3.p: --Hon. H.C. Goodwin, ex-member of Congress from the Madison and Oswego districts, died at Hamilton last night.

div3.head: The election in Georgia.
div3.p: --The popular majority in Georgia against Breckinridge is 2,000.

div3.head: Northern Markets.
div3.p:
--Flour depressed — Howard street $5.50; City Mills $5.25; Ohio offered at $5.37. Wheat dull and lower — red $1.30@1.38; white $1.40 $1.60. Corn buoyant — yellow 70@72 Mess pork $19-50.
Lard 12 Coffee dull.
Whiskey dull.

New York, Nov. 14.--Stocks unsettled, but generally better — New York Centrals 72 ¼, a fall of $2 since yesterday; Virginia 6's 87; Missouri 6's 72 ¼ a fall of ¼. Cotton heavy-- Uplands and Midchage 11 ½ @11 ½.
Flour firm — Southern $5.65@ $5.95. Wheat has an advancing tendency, and prices a shade better.
Corn buoyant — mixed 69@ 70 Pork heavy — mess $18 75@$19.12; prime $13@15.75.
Whiskey dull, and held at 21 Sugar dull.
Rosia dull at 42.
Rice heavy at 4 ½@4 3/8.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 18, Number 117, page 4.

div3.head: George III, and his keepers.
div3.p:
It would have been well if the errors of the physicians had been confined to ignorance. --But their negligence was still more reprehensible.
While the poor maniac was deprived of those tender offices which his wife and daughters might have rendered, he was abandoned to the care of low mercenaries, and so little discrimination was observed in the choice of his attendants, that the charge of his person devolved chiefly on a German page, named Erast, who was utterly unworthy to be trusted with the humblest of his fellow creatures.
This man, who had been raised by the patronage of His Majesty, repaid the kindness of his royal master with the most brutal ingratitude.
He went so far as to strike the helpless King, and on one occasion when his Majesty wished to protract his exercise in the gardens at Kew, Erast seized him in his arms, carried him into a chamber, and throwing him violently on a sofa, exclaimed in an insolent manner to his attendants: "There is your king for you." These outrages were perpetrated in the seclusion of the palace at Kew, to which the King had been removed in the month of October, at the instance of the Prince of Wales.
His Majesty had been persuaded to leave Windsor, to which he was much attached, by the promise that he should see his children at Kew. He entered the carriage cheerfully; but on passing through the iron gates of the Little Park, he put his hands before his face and burst into tears.
Recovering his composure, however, he talked to the equerries who accompanied him to the carriage in his ordinary hurried manner, pointing out the objects in the road, and anticipating the pleasure long denied him, of seeing his wife and daughters.
But on his arrival at Kew he found himself a prisoner.
Proceeding towards the apartments he usually occupied, he was stopped and conducted into a large room, where he found the pages who were to be his keepers waiting to receive him. The equerries, among whom was his faithful and valued servant, Gen. Harcourt, according to the orders they had received, withdrew.
The physicians also, who had accompanied the royal patient from Windsor, having consigned him to the charge of the pages, also thought proper to retire, and actually returned to London the same night.
The King then impatiently demanded to see his family; and the promise under which he had been induced to leave his Palace at Windsor was in cruel mockery fulfilled.
The Princesses were brought before the window; the King, on seeing them, rushed forward to lift the sash, but it was screwed down.
A paroxysm was the immediate consequence of this cruel restraint; the Princesses were hastily removed, and the King was dragged from the window, entreating to be allowed to speak to his children.--Massey's History of England.
